Remarks: Omitted in the language report, and in GHC's Hierarchical Libraries
REs are written as strings in source code: all backslashes must be doubled, harming readability.
Limited but REs are first-class citizens of the language with a specific /.../mod syntax.
REs are part of the language core library using PCRE built-in and an optional wrapper for (C code) ICU is available.

column5: can be bound to more powerful library, like PCRE or an alternative parser like LPeg.

Remarks: Standard library includes PCRE-based re and nre modules, as well as various alternatives (ex. strutils, pegs (Parsing Expression Grammar matching), strscans, parseutils, etc).
Free Pascal 2.6+ ships with TRegExpr from Sorokin and two other regular expression libraries
As of 2010[update], the standard module is generally regarded as deprecated
column5: [7] often recommended libraries are pcre (with full support for PCRE) and re (which is not as complete but claims better performance and provides frontends to popular syntaxes: PCRE, Perl, Posix, Emacs, shell globbing).

Software license: Artistic License, or GNU General Public License
Remarks: Full, central part of the language
Has two implementations, with PCRE being the more efficient in speed, functions
According to regex(3), available from at least 4.4BSD (if not earlier)
Python has two major implementations, the built in re and the regex library.
Tcl library doubles as a regular expression library.
usable for free on a limited scale on the Wolfram Development platform.
